usage_note: Used with friends or younger people. [Collo: 나는, 내가]

examples.en: I am a student.
How do I look?
Please help me.
I went to school yesterday.
I will go tomorrow.
I don't eat meat.
If I were you, I wouldn't do that.
I study and exercise.
Just trust me and follow.
I'll go first.

usage_note: Used with friends or equals. Be careful with strangers. [Collo: 너는, 네가]

examples.en: You are very pretty.
Where are you now?
You should come too.
Why didn't you come yesterday?
You will do great.
You don't know how I feel.
It's fine as long as you are okay.
I'm glad to meet you.
Mind your own business.
Did you eat?

usage_note: Reflects 'we-culture'; used even for personal things. [Collo: 우리 집, 우리 엄마]

examples.en: We are one team.
When shall we meet?
Let's have lunch together.
We met before.
We will get along well.
We don't have time.
I hope we win.
We are friends and colleagues.
Come visit our house.
Let's go now.
My name is Jisu.
What is your name?
Please write your name here.
I couldn't remember the name.
I'm going to name the baby.
I haven't decided on a name yet.
How about changing the name?
I was surprised to hear the name.
It lives up to its name.
What's your name?
That person is a teacher.
What kind of person do you like?
Be a good person.
There were many people yesterday.
You will meet a good person.
I'm not that kind of person.
As a human, you can't do that.
It's crowded because there are many people.
You never know what life brings.
Who is that person?

usage_note: Changes to '누가' when used as a subject. [Collo: 누구세요?]

examples.en: Who is this person?
Who are you waiting for?
Bring whoever you want.
Who were you with earlier?
I wonder who will come.
Nobody came.
If anyone knows, please tell me.
Who did you meet and what did you do?
By whose permission?
Who are you with?

usage_note: In Korea, this strictly refers to people of the same age. [Collo: 친구를 사귀다]

examples.en: He is my close friend.
Do you have many friends?
Let's be friends.
I met a friend yesterday.
I'm going to travel with a friend.
I don't have many friends.
When my friend comes, let's go together.
I met a friend and went shopping.
That's what friends are for.
I'll introduce my friend.

usage_note: Also a polite title for respected professionals. [Collo: 선생님 말씀]

examples.en: The teacher is in the classroom.
Are you a teacher?
Please listen to the teacher.
I asked the teacher a question.
I want to be a teacher later.
He is not a teacher.
We'll start when the teacher arrives.
I was happy to see the teacher.
The teacher is really passionate.
My teacher is really good.
I am a university student.
Do you have a student ID?
Act like a student.
I was a student back then too.
I will be a student next year.
I'm not a student anymore.
If you are a student, they give a discount.
I don't have money because I'm a student.
Student days are the best times.
Are you still a student?
This is a singer I like.
Which singer do you like?
Try singing like a singer.
That person was originally a singer.
I will become a famous singer.
I am not a singer.
If you're a singer, you should sing well.
The singer is singing a song.
Not everyone can be a singer.
That singer sings really well.

usage_note: Used when choosing from a set. [Collo: 어느 나라]

examples.en: Which one is better?
Which country are you from?
Which way shall we go?
Which restaurant did you go to?
Which university will you go to?
I don't like any of them.
It doesn't matter which way.
Which book do you study with?
When on earth will it be finished?
Which country are you from?
Korea is a beautiful country.
Which country do you want to visit?
Let's love our country.
I traveled to many countries.
I will live in another country.
Our country is not hot.
Cultures differ by country.
The country is developing.
It feels like I saved the country.
How is your country?
Korean is really fun.
Can you speak Korean?
Please try speaking in Korean.
I studied Korean for a year.
I will master Korean.
I'm not good at Korean yet.
If you know Korean, travel is easy.
I got a job after learning Korean.
Your Korean has improved a lot.
Is studying Korean hard?

usage_note: Root of greetings. [Collo: 안녕하세요, 안녕히 계세요]

examples.en: He is doing well.
Did you sleep well?
Say hi to your friend.
Did you get home safely yesterday?
I will say hi again tomorrow.
It's not good news.
If you're okay, that's all that matters.
We said hi and greeted each other.
Goodbye (to person staying).
Hi! How have you been?

usage_note: Used for meeting someone. [Collo: 만나서 반갑다]

examples.en: I'm so glad to meet you.
Are you glad to see me?
Please welcome them warmly.
It was really nice yesterday.
It'll be even better to see you next time.
You don't look that glad.
If you're glad, please smile.
I cried because I was so glad.
That's great news!
Friend, I'm so glad to see you!

usage_note: Use with seniors or in formal settings. [Collo: 저는, 제가]

examples.en: I am a student.
Shall I help you?
Please follow me.
I was busy yesterday.
I will definitely go.
I can't drink alcohol.
If it were me, I wouldn't have done it.
Please trust me and wait.
Excuse me (calling someone).
I know that too.

usage_note: Determines speech levels in Korea. [Collo: 나이를 먹다]

examples.en: My age is thirty.
How old are you?
Act your age.
I was young back then.
I'll be one year older next year.
Age is just a number.
If you're older, take care of your health.
As I got older, my thoughts changed.
Act your age (negative nuance).
How old are you?

usage_note: Often shortened to '뭐' in speech. [Collo: 무엇을, 뭐예요?]

examples.en: What is this?
How can I help you?
Ask me anything.
I forgot what I ate.
I wonder what it will become.
I don't want to do anything.
If anything is good, let me know.
What should I buy and take?
Health is the most important thing.
What is this?
I wash my face in the morning.
Did you wash your face?
Please wash your face quickly.
I washed my face earlier.
I will wash my face before sleeping.
I couldn't wash my face yet as I was busy.
You'll wake up after washing your face.
I wash my face and apply lotion.
I barely managed to wash my face before leaving.
You didn't wash your face, did you?
Your face is very pretty.
Is there something on your face?
Please show me your face.
My face was swollen yesterday.
Your complexion will look better.
I don't know that person's face.
You can tell if you see the face.
My face turned red so I was embarrassed.
You've lost so much weight (face became half).
What's wrong with your face?

usage_note: General movement away from the speaker. [Collo: 학교에 가다]

examples.en: I go to school.
Where are you going?
Please go home.
I went to Myeong-dong yesterday.
I will go to the airport tomorrow.
I'm not going to school today.
Call me when you go to school.
I go to school and study.
I'm going grocery shopping.
I'll go first.

usage_note: Movement toward the speaker. [Collo: 집에 오다]

examples.en: A friend comes to my house.
When are you coming?
Please come this way.
It rained yesterday.
I will come soon.
The bus isn't coming.
Call me when you come home.
I come home and rest.
Rain or shine.
Come quickly!

usage_note: Also used for 'drinking' soup or medicine sometimes. [Collo: 밥을 먹다]

examples.en: I eat a meal.
Did you eat lunch?
Please eat a lot (Enjoy your meal).
I ate bread this morning.
I will eat Samgyeopsal for dinner.
I don't eat breakfast.
If you're hungry, eat this.
I eat and then drink coffee.
To get older (eat age).
What are you eating?

usage_note: [Collo: 물을 마시다, 커피 한 잔 마시다]

examples.en: I drink coffee.
What do you want to drink?
Drink plenty of water.
I drank a lot yesterday.
I will drink cold water.
I don't drink coffee.
If you're thirsty, drink water.
I drink milk and go to sleep.
Shall we go for a cup of tea?
Drink some juice.

usage_note: Also used for 'taking' an exam. [Collo: 영화를 보다, 시험을 보다]

examples.en: I watch a movie.
Did you see that?
Please look over here.
I saw a friend yesterday.
I will take an exam tomorrow.
I don't watch TV.
If you have time, watch a movie.
I watch a movie and eat.
Please have a taste.
Look at this.
I go to sleep early.
Where are you going to sleep?
Please sleep well (polite).
I slept late yesterday.
I'm going to sleep now.
I'm not sleeping yet.
If you're sleepy, go to sleep.
I wash up and sleep.
To take a nap.
Good night.
I wake up in the morning.
What time did you wake up?
Please wake up quickly.
I woke up early.
I will wake up early tomorrow.
I haven't woken up yet.
Wash your face when you wake up.
I wake up and exercise.
To stand up from a seat.
Are you up?

usage_note: Irregular verb: ㄷ changes to ㄹ. [Collo: 음악을 듣다]

examples.en: I listen to a song.
Can you hear me?
Please listen to the teacher.
I heard the news.
I will listen to music.
I can't hear you.
You'll know it when you hear it.
I study while listening to music.
To be obedient.
Listen to this song.
I speak in Korean.
Who did you tell?
Please say that again.
I said it's a secret.
I will tell you later.
Don't say anything.
If you tell me, I'll listen.
I regretted after saying it.
That makes no sense / No way.
Tell me honestly.

usage_note: Multipurpose verb. [Collo: 편지를 쓰다, 돈을 쓰다]

examples.en: I write a letter.
Can I use this ballpoint pen?
Please write your name.
I spent a lot of money.
I will write in my diary.
I don't use/write it.
Use it if you need to.
Read it after writing.
To wear a hat.
Did you write this?
I read a book.
Did you finish reading?
Please read slowly.
I read the newspaper.
I will read it later.
I haven't read it yet.
It'll be fun if you read it.
Tell me after you read it.
To read one's mind.
Read some books.

usage_note: Very versatile; forms many verbs. [Collo: 공부를 하다, 운동을 하다]

examples.en: I do my homework.

Please do your best.
I exercised.
I'll do it later.
I'm not doing it.
You can do it / It'll work if you do it.
I want to do it.
Don't even mention it.
What are you doing?

usage_note: Antonym: 없다. [Collo: 친구가 있다, 집에 있다]

Please stay here.
I was there yesterday.
I will be there tomorrow.
I don't have it / It's not here.
Give it to me if you have it.
I want to stay.
To stay still.
I'm here.

usage_note: Antonym: 있다. [Collo: 돈이 없다, 시간이 없다]

examples.en: I don't have money.
Is nobody there?
Say that it's not there.
There was no opportunity.
It won't be there tomorrow.
It's there (Opposite).
If we don't have it, we must buy it.
I couldn't buy it because it wasn't there.
To be absurd.
I don't have money.
I give water.
Shall I give you this?
Give me some milk, please.
I gave a gift yesterday.
I will give it to you later.
I won't give it.
I'd be thankful if you give it.
To give and take.
To help (give help).
I'll give this to you.
I receive pocket money.
Did you answer the phone?
Please take this.
I received a gift.
I will get my salary.
I couldn't receive it.
Tell me when you get it.
Check after receiving.
To be popular.
Accept my gift.
I buy clothes.
What did you buy?
Please buy some apples.
I bought it at the mart.
I'm going to buy a new car.
I'm not buying it because it's expensive.
Buy it if it's cheap.
I'll buy it and send it to you.
To treat someone.
Where did you buy this?
They sell it at the store.
Do you sell this?
Please sell it cheap.
Sold it all.
I will sell it tomorrow.
They don't sell it here.
Let me know if you sell it.
I don't want to sell it.

I already knew.
You'll know soon.
I don't know (Opposite).
Tell me if you know.
I want to know.

Do you know that?

You have no idea?
Just say you don't know.
I didn't know before.
Nobody will know.
I know (Opposite).
Ask if you don't know.
I couldn't do it because I didn't know.
To pretend not to know.
I really don't know.

usage_note: Use '우리 가족' to say 'my family'. [Collo: 가족사진, 가족 여행]

examples.en: My family consists of four people.

I met my family last week.

I worry if my family gets sick.

This is our family photo.
My father is an office worker.

Please call your father.
I went hiking with my father yesterday.
I will become like my father later.
My father doesn't drink.
Let's eat together when my father arrives.
My father is strict and my mother is kind.

My dad is really cool.

My mother will come tomorrow.

usage_note: Used by males only. [Collo: 우리 형, 친형]

examples.en: I have one older brother.

My brother will get married soon.

My brother is tall and I am short.
An older brother is better than a younger one.

usage_note: Used by females only. [Collo: 우리 오빠, 아는 오빠]

examples.en: My older brother is good at studying.

Try calling him 'Oppa'.

My brother will be here soon.
I don't have an older brother.

usage_note: Used by females only. [Collo: 우리 언니, 아는 언니]

examples.en: My older sister has a lot of clothes.
Are you close with your sister?
Please listen to your sister.
I got clothes from my sister.
My sister will go on a trip tomorrow.
I don't look like my sister.
Let's play together when my sister comes.
My sister is pretty and kind.

Sister, what is this?

usage_note: Used by males only. [Collo: 우리 누나, 아는 누나]

examples.en: My older sister is a nurse.
Do you have an older sister?
Please ask your sister.
I fought with my sister yesterday.
My sister will cook for me.
I'm not afraid of my sister.
It's a big problem if my sister finds out.

usage_note: Generic term. Add '남/여' to specify gender. [Collo: 남동생, 여동생]

I will go to see my grandmother tomorrow.
My grandmother is not in Seoul.
Grandmother will be surprised if she sees it.
I met my grandmother and got pocket money.
Grandmother is so full of affection.
My grandmother's Kimchi is really delicious.

usage_note: Use '우리 집' for 'my house'. [Collo: 집들이, 집에 가다]

examples.en: I am at home now.
Where is your house?
Please come visit my house.
I bought a house last month.

examples.ko: 내년에는 더 큰 집으로 이사 갈 거예요.
examples.en: I will move to a larger house next year.
I'm not going home today.
Call me when you get home.

Please tidy up your room.
I was in the room earlier.

The room is not that big.
I feel good when the room is clean.

I will buy a new bed.
This bed is not comfortable.
I wish the bed were big.
I read a book on the bed and then slept.
The bed is science (famous ad catchphrase).
My bed is really good.
There is a book on the desk.

Please clear your desk.
I assembled the desk yesterday.

examples.ko: 조금 더 큰 책상을 살 거예요.
examples.en: I will buy a slightly larger desk.
The desk is too narrow, so it's uncomfortable.
I study better if there is a desk.
I sit at the desk and do my homework.
He's just a bookworm (only knows books).

This chair is very comfortable.
Is there one more chair?
Please sit on the chair.
The chair broke.
I will choose a pretty chair.
The chair is not hard/stiff.
It's uncomfortable if the chair is high.
Please bring a chair.
To stay focused at the desk (butt on chair).
That chair is mine.

Would you open the door?
Please make sure to close the door when leaving.
I locked the door.

examples.ko: 누가 오면 문을 열어 줄 거예요.
examples.en: I will open the door when someone comes.
The door won't open.
It's cool if you open the door.
I opened the door and went outside.
I was turned away at the door.
Hey, close the door.
Sunlight is coming through the window.
May I close the window?
Please open the window.
I cleaned the windows yesterday.
I will fix the window tomorrow.
I don't open the window because it's cold.
It's noisy if you open the window.

Please tidy up the kitchen.
I was in the kitchen earlier.
I will have a large kitchen later.
Our kitchen is not big.
I feel good if the kitchen is clean.

examples.en: You changed your mind (entering vs leaving toilet).

Please rest in the living room.
I slept in the living room earlier.
I will put a carpet in the living room.
The living room is not that spacious.

examples.en: The mountain will get deeper in the future.
The swimming pool is not deep.

It's deep, so the bottom isn't visible.

The water there is really deep.

The water here is shallow.

Did you wash your hands clean?

If it's clean, you feel refreshed.

The world is so unfair (dirty - slang nuance).

The classroom was quiet earlier.
It will get quieter at night.

I can study well if it's quiet.
It's good because it's quiet and cozy.

Yesterday's party was really noisy.

It's not as noisy as I thought.
I can't sleep if it's noisy.
I can't hear the phone because it's noisy.
Stop making a fuss.
Ugh, so noisy!
The room is light and bright.
Is the screen too bright?
Please wear bright-colored clothes.
The moon was very bright yesterday.
The future will be bright.
This lamp is not very bright.
If it's bright, it's good for reading.

You have keen eyesight (or are perceptive).
You really have a bright impression.
The alley is too dark.

It's dark, so turn on the light.
Inside the room was dark earlier.

examples.en: It will get dark as if it's about to rain.
It doesn't seem dark to my eyes.

I can't see the face because it's dark.
You have a dark (gloomy) expression.
It's too dark here.
The coffee is very hot.
Is the soup too hot?
Eat it quickly while it's hot.
The sunlight was really hot yesterday.
The pot will get hot soon.
This water is not hot.
Drink carefully if it's hot.
I burned my tongue because it was hot.
I'll show you what's what! (Take a taste of 'hotness').
Hey, this is really hot.
The ice water is very cold.
Why are your hands so cold?
Please give me a cold drink.
The juice I drank earlier was cold.

This milk is not cold.

The water is really cold.
The spring breeze is very warm.
Shall I give you another cup of tea? (It's warm).
Dress warmly and go out.
The room was very warm yesterday.
It will be warmer tomorrow than today.
This blanket is not very warm.
I sleep well if it's warm.
It's a warm and cozy feeling.
You're a warm-hearted person.
Wow, this soup is really warm.
The autumn breeze is very cool.
Is the pool water refreshing/cool?
Let's go somewhere cool.
The Naengmyeon I ate yesterday was really refreshing.
It will be cool if you turn on the air conditioner.
It's not very cool here.
I feel better when it's cool/refreshing.
I want to stay because it's cool.
Ah, that's refreshing! (Said even with hot soup).
Hey, the breeze is really cool.
This bread is too hard.
Is the bed too hard?
Eat hard foods carefully.
My shoulders were really stiff (hard) yesterday.
This dough will get hard later.
This pillow is not hard.
It's hard to eat if it's hard.
My teeth hurt because it's hard.
Your expression is too stiff (formal/stern).
This candy is really hard.
This fabric is very soft.
Why is your skin so smooth?
Give a soft smile.
The meat I ate yesterday was really tender (soft).
Your hair will get smoother in the future.
This toothbrush is not soft.
I feel good if it's soft/smooth.
It's a soft and delicious cake.
Your way of speaking is very gentle (soft).
This doll is really soft.
This idea is really new.
Anything new happening?
Challenge yourself with something new.
His transformation was really new/refreshing.
I will start in a new environment tomorrow.

examples.ko: 저는 새로운 건 별로 안 좋아해요.
examples.en: I don't really like new things.
Everyone will like it if it's new.
It's a new and fresh feeling.
I feel like a new person (refreshed).
This song is really new/fresh.
This book is really old.
How old is this photo?
Organize the old items.
We've been friends since long ago.

examples.ko: 나중에는 이것도 오래된 역사가 될 거예요.
examples.en: This will also become old history later.
My clothes are not old.
Value goes up as it gets old (antique).
It's worn out because it's old.
I've grown attached to it as time passed (as it got old).
This building is really old.

examples.ko: 저 사람 제 친구 같지 않아요?
examples.en: Doesn't that person look like my friend?
Have the same mind as at the beginning.
He/She used to have the same dream as me.
Tomorrow will be the same as today.

examples.ko: 이건 제가 알던 것과 같지 않아요.
examples.en: This is not the same as what I knew.
Combine them into one if they are the same.
It's confusing because they're the same.
It was a hellish (like hell) day.
You and I have the same clothes.

examples.ko: 이 사과와 저 사과는 맛이 달라요.
examples.en: This apple and that apple have different tastes.
What is so different?
Please look for a different method.
My personality was different from now before.
The result will be different tomorrow.
I am not different from them.
Check again if it's different.
It's more special because it's different.
It's on a different level.
This and that are different.
My sibling and I have similar faces.
Is your personality similar to his?

It was very similar to what I saw yesterday.
It will become more similar in the future.
This is not similar at all.
I'll just use it if it's similar.
I keep getting it wrong because they're similar.
It's about the same (six of one, half a dozen of the other).
You two are really similar.

usage_note: Often confused with 다르다. [Collo: 답이 틀리다]

examples.en: The exam answer is wrong.

Be careful not to be wrong/make a mistake.
The calculation was wrong earlier.
I won't be wrong ever again.
My thinking is not wrong.
If it's wrong, do it again from the beginning.
I'm upset because it's wrong.
There's no hope/potential for this (it's wrong from the bud).
These are all wrong.
My answer is correct.
Does the size fit you well?
Circle it if it's correct.
Yesterday the prediction was correct.

examples.ko: 곧 정답을 맞힐 거예요. (To guess right)
examples.en: I will guess the right answer soon.
This doesn't fit my aptitude.
Let's depart right away if it's right/fits.
Whether it's right or wrong isn't important.

examples.ko: 입이 짧아서 입맛에 안 맞나 봐요.
examples.en: I guess it doesn't suit your taste because you're a picky eater.
Oh, you're right!
Write a suitable word here.
Is this seat suitable?

That choice was appropriate at that time.

examples.ko: 앞으로 더 알맞은 기회가 올 거예요.
examples.en: A more suitable opportunity will come in the future.
This is not suitable for our situation.
If it's suitable, proceed as it is.
I cooked it appropriately and served it.
It's ripened/cooked just right.
This is just right (suitable) for me.
My father reads the newspaper every day.

Please check the front page of the newspaper.
I found a famous restaurant in the newspaper yesterday.

examples.ko: 내일 신문에 이 기사가 실릴 거예요.
examples.en: This article will be in tomorrow's newspaper.
I don't really read newspapers these days.

examples.ko: 신문을 읽으면 세상을 알 수 있어요.
examples.en: If you read the newspaper, you can know the world.
I buy a newspaper and drink coffee.
He's old-fashioned, so he only sticks to newspapers.
Bring me the newspaper.

What kind of magazine do you like?
Try reading this magazine.

A new magazine issue will be out soon.
This magazine is not that interesting.
I want to buy it if the magazine is pretty.
I looked at the magazine and got information.
You look like a magazine pictorial.
That magazine is really famous.

There will be lots of good news tomorrow.
I don't believe the news.
Watching the news improves your vocabulary.

Worrying about the news day and night.

I did an interview on the broadcast yesterday.
They will broadcast it again tomorrow.
This is not a rerun.
You'll become famous once the broadcast goes out.

You must be happy to be on TV/broadcast.
That broadcast is really funny.
My favorite program is starting.

I watched that program yesterday.

This program is not difficult.

The regular program has been scheduled.
This program is really useful.

I saw a funny ad yesterday.
I will film an ad tomorrow.
I don't really believe advertisements.

Please bring me the phone.
I bought a new phone yesterday.
I will fix the phone tomorrow.
There is no telephone at home.
Answer the phone if it rings.
I picked up the phone and dialed the number.

Should I lend you the phone?

Can you live without a smartphone?
Please put down your smartphone.
I dropped my smartphone yesterday.
I will change my smartphone later.
My smartphone is not expensive.
You're not bored if you have a smartphone.
I found the way by looking at my smartphone.
The smartphone never leaves your hand.
My smartphone is really good.

Text me when you arrive.

I'm going to write a long text later.
The text hasn't arrived yet.

examples.ko: 내일은 더 많은 사람이 올 거예요.

examples.en: People come before money (Life is more important than wealth).

usage_note: Respectful counter/noun for people. [Collo: 이 분, 저 분]

examples.en: This person is my teacher.
Which person is the boss?
Anyone who needs it, please take it.
A certain person came by earlier.
An important person will arrive soon.
That person is not our employee.
If it's someone who needs help, we should help.
He/She is the new person and is very kind.
It's a split-second situation (pun on '분').

examples.ko: 저 분 누구셔? (Wait, use '저 사람 누구야' for informal).
examples.en: (Honorifics are rarely used in strict informal speech).
Welcome to all the people here.
Where are those people now?
People from abroad, please come this way.
Many people attended yesterday.

examples.ko: 나중에는 더 많은 분들이 알게 될 거예요.
examples.en: More people will know about it later.

examples.ko: 모든 분들이 다 오신 건 아니에요.
examples.en: Not everyone (all people) has arrived.
If the people agree, let's start.
It ended well thanks to the people who helped.
Let's respect the elderly.
(Plural 'people' informal is '사람들').
Greet elders first when you see them.
What's good about becoming an adult?
Act like an adult.
I wanted to be an adult when I was young.

examples.ko: 나중에는 저도 멋진 어른이 될 거예요.
examples.en: I will become a cool adult later.
He's grown in body, but he's not an adult (mentally).
Be polite when an elder is present.
Both adults and children like it.
I greeted the village elders.
You're a grown adult now.
The child is playing in the park.
How old is that child?
They are just children, so please be understanding.
I went to the zoo with the children yesterday.
I will go pick up the child tomorrow.
I don't have children yet.
Soothe the child if he/she cries.
I smile because the child is smiling.
Oh! You startled me! (pun on exclamation).
That child is really cute.
The owner of this shop is really kind.
Who is the owner of this bag?
Get the owner's permission.
I met the landlord (house owner) yesterday.

examples.ko: 나중에 큰 건물의 주인이 될 거예요.
examples.en: I will be the owner of a big building later.
I am not the owner of this dog.
If the owner is not here, come back later.
I found the owner and returned the item.
You are the master of your own life.
Is there no owner for this?
The restaurant is full of customers.
How many guests are coming today?
Please serve tea to the guest.
A precious guest came to our house yesterday.
There will be more customers tomorrow.
We can't receive customers/guests right now.
There's a saying that the customer is king.
I saw the guests off and then cleaned up.
An uninvited guest.
A guest is here.

usage_note: Used for unmarried young women. [Collo: 꽃집 아가씨]

examples.en: That young lady is very elegant.
Who is that young lady?
(Polite address: 아가씨!)
I saw the young lady working at the restaurant yesterday.
She will grow up to be a wonderful young lady.
I'm not a young lady, I'm a middle-aged woman (ajumma).
If you're a young lady, mind your attire (older generation's advice).
The young lady smiled and greeted.
It feels good to be called 'Miss/Agassi'.
Hey, look at that young lady.

usage_note: General term for men older than oneself. [Collo: 택배 아저씨]

examples.en: The security guard (ajusshi) is diligent every day.
What is that mister's name?
Mister, some water here please.
I met a kind man on the street yesterday.
I'll eventually become an 'ajusshi' too.
I am not a scary mister.
Move aside if the mister comes by.
I talked to the man and found the way.
As comfortable as the man next door.
That mister is really funny.
The restaurant lady gave me a lot of rice.
Is that lady someone you know?
Ma'am, please clear this.
I greeted the market lady earlier.
I want to become a benevolent lady later.

examples.ko: 저는 그렇게 나이 많은 아주머니가 아니에요.
examples.en: I am not that old of a lady.
Help the lady if she is busy.
I met the lady and had a chat.
All the neighborhood ladies have gathered.
Who is that lady?

usage_note: Also used for elderly men. [Collo: 외할아버지]

examples.en: My grandfather is healthy.
How old (honorific) is your grandfather?
Listen carefully to grandfather's words.
I went to my grandfather's house yesterday.
I will take a walk with grandfather tomorrow.
That person is not my grandfather.
Give up your seat if an elderly man is present.
I helped the grandfather and was praised.
You have a grandfather-like (warm) smile.
My grandpa is really cool.

usage_note: Also used for elderly women. [Collo: 친할머니]

examples.en: The food grandmother made is the best.
Where are you going, grandmother?
Grandmother, please sit here.
I called my grandmother yesterday.
Grandmother's birthday (honorific) will be coming soon.
Grandmother doesn't like spicy things.
I feel sad if grandmother is sick.
I took my grandmother to the hospital.
Grandmother's hand is the healing hand (folk medicine).
I miss my grandmother.

usage_note: Respectful version of '이름'. [Collo: 성함이 어떻게 되세요?]

examples.en: My name (formal) is Chul-soo Kim.
What is your name (honorific)?
Please write your name here.
I asked for that person's name earlier.

examples.ko: 나중에 제 성함으로 책을 낼 거예요.
examples.en: I will publish a book under my name later.
I don't know the name (honorific) well.
If the name is correct, please confirm.
I checked the name and guided them.
You're living up to your name.
(Informal for '성함' is '이름').
I am the same age as my friend.
How old are you?
Act your age.

examples.ko: 작년에는 나이가 한 살 더 어렸죠.
examples.en: I was one year younger last year.

examples.ko: 앞으로 나이를 더 먹으면 깨닫게 될 거예요.
examples.en: You'll realize it when you get older (eat more age).
Age is just a number.
If you are old (high age), you have much experience.
I asked the age and heard the answer.
Please act your age (literally: Do your age-worth).
Are you the same age as me?
My grandfather is old (his age is high).
How old are your parents (honorific)?
They are elderly (have age), so treat them carefully.
Before, they looked young for their age.

examples.ko: 곧 여든이 되는 연세가 되실 거예요.
examples.en: They will soon be at the age of eighty.
You (honorific) don't look very old.
As you get older, health is the best thing.

examples.ko: 연세가 많으셔서 귀가 잘 안 들리세요.
examples.en: They are elderly, so they can't hear well.
You are quite advanced in years (respectful).
(Don't use '연세' in informal speech).
The teacher's words are truly right.
What did you say (honorific)?
Please listen to what I (formal) say.

I will tell you again later (honorific).
Don't say such things (honorific).

He/She finished speaking and stood up.
Thank you for just saying so.
(Use '말' in informal settings).
I asked my friend for a big favor today.
Can you do me a favor?
Please, listen to my request.
I received a difficult request yesterday.

examples.ko: 나중에 꼭 부탁드릴 일이 있을 거예요.
examples.en: I'll surely have something to ask of you later.
I can't grant such a request.
If you have a favor, tell me anytime.
I made a request and am waiting for a reply.
I'm asking for a favor despite my shame (formal).
Let me ask you a favor.
I am really thankful for your help.
What are you so thankful for?
If you're thankful, buy me a meal.
I was very thankful yesterday.
I will definitely say thank you later.
I'm not thankful at all.
If you're thankful, that's enough.
I feel both thankful and sorry.
I can't thank you enough.
Thanks so much!
I am really sorry for being late.
Are you sorry to me?
If you're sorry, apologize.
I was so sorry yesterday.

examples.ko: 나중에는 미안할 일 안 만들 거예요.
examples.en: I won't do things to be sorry for later.
I'm not sorry at all.
If you're sorry, be good to me next time.
I can't look at you because I'm so sorry.
I'm sorry' is not enough.
Hey, I'm really sorry.

usage_note: Added to fill 20th slot. [Collo: 식사 예절]

examples.en: Table etiquette is important in Korea.
Is that behavior according to etiquette?
Please follow the etiquette well.
I received etiquette training when I was young.

examples.ko: 앞으로 더 예절 바른 사람이 될 거예요.
examples.en: I will become a more well-mannered person.
His behavior is not polite/etiquette.
You'll be looked down on if you have no manners.

They call (Korea) the 'country of courteous people in the East'.
You really have no manners.
I do my homework first and then play.
May I go (do it) first?

He arrived before me (first).
I will come first tomorrow.
I don't want to go first.
If you go ahead, I'll wait for you.
I washed first and then ate.
Excuse me for leaving first.
I'm going first!

usage_note: Sometime in the future. [Collo: 나중에 봐요]

examples.en: Let's talk again later.

examples.ko: 나중에 시간 좀 내줄 수 있어요?
examples.en: Can you spare some time later?
Please handle this matter later.
I heard the news later.
I will definitely come back later.
There is no "later," so do it now.
It might be late if you come later.
I'm busy now, so let's meet later.
Don't regret it later.
Let's meet later.
This is my first time in Korea.
It's your first time doing this, so it's hard, right?
Please do it again from the beginning.
At first, I couldn't eat kimchi.
I will work with the same mind as at the beginning.
It's not the first time, but the second.
If it's your first time, I'll help you.
We met for the first time and shook hands.
How do you do? (Nice to meet you for the first time).
I'm trying this for the first time.
Today is the last class.
Is this the last question?
Please do your best until the very end.
Yesterday was the last chance.
Tomorrow will be the last day.
It's not the end (last) yet.
I think I'll be so sad if it's the last time.
I said my final goodbye and left.
It's precarious like the last leaf.
Don't you have anything last to say?
I met a friend a while ago.
Where were you earlier?
Try smiling like you did earlier.
I was really busy earlier.
(Refers to the immediate past of today).
You weren't like that earlier.
It would have been good if you had come earlier.
You're eating again after eating earlier?
It was fine until just a while ago.
I saw you earlier.

usage_note: A while later today. [Collo: 이따가 봐요]

examples.en: Let's meet later this evening.
Do you have some time later?
Please call again later (today).
(Refers to the upcoming time today).
I will do my homework later today.
I won't be busy later.
What if it rains later?
I'm busy now, so let's do it later.
See you later (today)!
Come to my house later.

meaning: Soon / In a moment / Just now

examples.en: The rain will stop soon.
Can you finish it all in a moment?
I'll be back soon, so wait.
He just went out.
I will arrive soon.
I don't think it will be done soon.
If it finishes soon, let's eat together.
You're hungry again right after eating?
It looks like they might cry at any moment.
I'll be there soon!
I just received a call.
What did you just say (honorific)?
(Cannot be used in commands).
An accident just happened.
(Focuses on the immediate past).

examples.ko: 방금 한 건 제 실수가 아니에요.
examples.en: What happened just now wasn't my mistake.
If you just arrived, rest a bit.
I just arrived and am unpacking.
It just came out piping hot.
I just finished it now.
It's already past 12 o'clock.
Did you finish it all already?
Don't leave already; stay longer.

By tomorrow, it'll already be a week.

Time is so fast (already).
What? Did he go already?
He has already gone home.
Have you already booked everything?
It's already over, so stop now.
I already checked yesterday.
It will already be dark when we arrive.

examples.ko: 이미 안 늦었어요. (Strange, use 아직 안 늦었어요).
examples.en: (이미 is rare with simple negation).
If it's already late, nothing can be helped.
It's already decided, so it can't be changed.
It's already spilled water (no use crying over spilt milk).
I already know everything.
I'm still at school.
Is it not finished yet?
Don't go yet.
It was still okay until yesterday.
I'll still be busy tomorrow.
I don't know yet.
If it's still far, I'll come later.
I'm still hungry, so I want to eat more.
(You've) still got it! (Slang).
I haven't slept yet.
Please say it one more time (again).
May I ask again?
Please start again from the beginning.
I called again yesterday.
I'll come again tomorrow.
I will never do that again.

examples.ko: 다시 하면 더 잘할 수 있어요.
examples.en: You can do better if you do it again.
It was wrong, so I wrote it again.
Even if I'm born again, it's only you.
Try this again.
I eat bread. Also, I drink milk.
It's raining again?
Please come again tomorrow.
I was late again yesterday.
We will meet again next time.
I won't do it again now.
I'll be angry if you do that again.
I do my homework and also review.
Isn't he/she crazy? (Be careful with slang).
See you again tomorrow!
Finally, the weekend has come.
Have you finally finished everything?
(Used for long-awaited results).
Finally, the exam is over.
By tomorrow, it's finally vacation.
It's too early to say "finally."
I'll be so glad when we finally meet.
I finally passed and cried with joy.
Finally, it's the long-awaited moment.
Finally, it's over!
I worked hard and eventually succeeded.
How did it turn out in the end?
(Focuses on final outcome).
Eventually, it rained so I couldn't go.
In the end, I will win.

You shouldn't eventually give up.
In the end, I was late and missed the bus.
Everything will be fine in the end.
See, wasn't I right in the end?

What are you especially curious about?

Yesterday was especially crowded.
Tomorrow will be especially colder.

It looks unique (pun on 'special').
I especially like you.

examples.ko: 곧 갑자기 좋은 일이 생길 거예요.
examples.en: Something good will suddenly happen soon.
It's not sudden at all.
It's flustering if you come suddenly.
I was surprised because you suddenly appeared.
Suddenly the mood turned cold (slang).
Hey, why are you acting like that suddenly?
I sometimes eat spicy food.
Do you sometimes think of me?

I sometimes drank before.
I'll stop by sometimes in the future.

examples.ko: 가끔은 안 하고 싶을 때도 있죠.
examples.en: There are times I don't want to do it sometimes.
It's good to be alone sometimes.
I get scolded because I'm sometimes late.
It happens once in a while.
I sometimes miss you.
I go to the library often.
Do you exercise often?
Let's meet often.
I played often when I was young.
I'll come often from now on.
I don't smile often.
You get close if you see each other often.
I'm worried because I'm sick often.
Please come very often.
Let's contact each other often.
I always wake up early.
Do you always drink coffee here?
Please always stay healthy.
He was always kind.
I will always cheer for you.
It's not always like that.
Blessings come if you always smile.
It's hard to see you because you're always busy.
Always stay alert.
Let's always stay together.

usage_note: Usually refers to the side across a road/river. [Collo: 길 건너편]

examples.en: The bank is across the street.

Please wait on the opposite side.

If you go to the opposite side, a big park appears.

The grass is always greener on the other side (The other's rice cake looks bigger).

usage_note: Focuses on facing each other. [Collo: 호텔 맞은편]

examples.en: There is a cafe facing the restaurant.
Would you like to sit opposite me?
Please enter the building opposite.
I sat in the opposite seat yesterday.

examples.ko: 곧 맞은편에 새 건물이 들어설 거예요.
examples.en: A new building will soon stand on the opposite side.
This is not opposite the subway station.
If there is no one on the opposite side, come this way.
I looked opposite and waved my hand.
I almost hit a car coming from the opposite side.

usage_note: Action of moving across. [Collo: 길을 건너다]

examples.en: I cross the street at the crosswalk.
Where do I have to cross the street?
Please cross carefully, watching for cars.
I crossed the street via the overpass earlier.
We will cross the bridge soon.
You shouldn't cross by jaywalking.
The station is visible right after you cross.
Cross the street and go to the right.
The die is cast (The river has been crossed).
Let's cross quickly!
Past the library is my house.
Is there a bus that passes here?
Please go past a little further.
I passed the intersection earlier.
We will pass the tunnel soon.
We haven't passed that stop yet.
It's hard to come back once you pass.
Pass the bank and walk straight.
Time is medicine, and it passed quickly.
I just passed your house.
We are going in the same direction.
Which direction shall we go?
Please go in the opposite direction.
I took the wrong direction earlier.
I will explore a different direction tomorrow.

examples.ko: 이 방향은 역으로 가는 게 아니에요.
examples.en: This direction is not for going to the station.
Let's go together if the direction is right.
I turned (changed direction) and slowed down.
Set the direction of your life.
This is the right direction, right?

Do I have to go to the right?
Look to the right.
I went to the right path earlier.
They will repair the building on the right tomorrow.
The right side is blocked.
If you turn right, a park appears.
I looked to the right and waved my hand.
He is the boss's right-hand man.
Go to the right.
I see the post office on the left.
Is the left side closer?
Please get off through the left door.
There was a sound from the left earlier.

examples.ko: 곧 왼쪽에 큰 상가가 생길 거예요.
examples.en: A large shopping center will soon open on the left.

The background (back side) is pretty.

The front view is very good.

If the inner part is narrow, wait outside.

I don't know the inner workings (affairs) well.

Don't go to the outer side.
I waited on the outer side earlier.
The outer construction will end soon.

Please check the lower part.

I will wipe the lower windows tomorrow.
The lower part is not dangerous.

examples.ko: 곧 우리 사이가 더 좋아질 거예요.

examples.ko: 이건 너와 나 사이의 문제가 아니야.

examples.ko: 내일은 거실 가운데에 카펫을 깔 거예요.
examples.en: I will lay a carpet in the middle of the living room tomorrow.

If the middle is empty, go in.

Come to the middle.

The surroundings were really noisy yesterday.

examples.ko: 곧 집 주변에 공원이 생길 거예요.
examples.en: A park will soon be built around the house.
None of the people around know.
It's good to study if the surroundings are quiet.

Please get up now.

You feel refreshed if you wash.

meaning: To wipe / To brush / To polish

examples.en: I brush my teeth three times a day.
Did you polish your shoes?
Please wipe the floor clean.
I wiped the windows earlier.
I will wipe my glasses later.
I haven't wiped it yet, so be careful.
It will be sparkling if you wipe/polish it.

Wipe this for me.

Are you wearing new clothes?
Please wear a pretty coat.
I wore a suit yesterday.
I will wear a Hanbok tomorrow.
I don't wear these clothes.
You'll look prettier if you wear it.

Try this on.

Please sit down and take off your hat.
I took off my socks as soon as I got home.
I'll take off my clothes and wash later.
Don't take it off yet because it's cold.

He/She was cleared (took off) of the charges.
Take off your shoes and come in.
I'm going to put on my sneakers.
Are you wearing dress shoes?
Your feet hurt, so please wear comfortable shoes.
I wore sandals yesterday.
I will wear new rain boots tomorrow.
I'm not wearing socks.
Your feet are warm if you wear them.
I put on my shoes and tied the laces.
Wearing flower shoes (going to a good place/getting married).
Try wearing these shoes.

Please wear glasses when it's dark.
I didn't wear glasses before.
I will wear new glasses tomorrow.

You can see well if you wear glasses.

Don't look with prejudice (colored glasses).
Are you wearing glasses?

examples.ko: 아침에 화장하는 데 한 시간 걸렸어요.

I will put on makeup before going to the party.

The makeup looks good on you (makeup power).

Did you go to work today?
Please go to work early so you're not late.
I didn't go to work yesterday because it was Sunday.
I will go to work earlier tomorrow.
I'm not going to work today.
I drink coffee first when I get to work.

He/She "stamped the attendance" (arrived).

I get off work happily at 6 PM.
Did you get off work already?
Please get off work if you're finished.
I got off work late yesterday because of overtime.
I will definitely get off work on time today.
I haven't gotten off work yet.
Let's have dinner together when you get off work.

Getting off work exactly on time (knife-like) is the best.

Are you working now?
Please work with focus.

I will work from home tomorrow.

I feel a sense of accomplishment when I work.

The work is piled up like a mountain.
I'm working right now.

meaning: To rest / To take a break

examples.en: I rest well at home on weekends.

If you're tired, please rest for a while.
I rested all day yesterday.
I will rest at a cafe tomorrow.

You feel better if you rest.
Rest and then start again.
You're breathing (taking a breath).
Shall we rest a bit?
I take a walk in the park after lunch.
Do you want to take a walk together?
Please take a walk while breathing fresh air.
I took a walk with my dog yesterday.
I will take a walk tomorrow morning.
I'm not taking a walk because it's raining.
It's good for health if you take a walk.

Want to go for a walk with me?

What kind of exercise do you do?
Please exercise for your health.
I worked out at the pool yesterday.

examples.ko: 내일은 친구와 테니스를 치며 운동할 거예요.
examples.en: I will exercise by playing tennis with a friend tomorrow.

Your body gets strong if you exercise.

Let's work out together.

meaning: To eat out / To dine out

I will eat out at an Italian restaurant tomorrow.

examples.ko: 외식하면 설거지 안 해도 돼서 좋아요.
examples.en: It's good to eat out because you don't have to do dishes.

Please shop during the sale period.
I shopped for groceries at the mart yesterday.
I will shop online tomorrow.

Shopping relieves stress.

Shall we go shopping?

Please cook for yourself for your health.
I cooked pasta for my friends yesterday.
I will cook Bulgogi tomorrow.
I'm not good at cooking.

examples.ko: 요리하면 집 안 가득 냄새가 나요.
examples.en: The whole house smells if you cook.
I cooked and set the table.
Your cooking skills are great.
I'll cook for you.

Let's clean together.

examples.ko: 내일은 흰 옷만 모아서 빨래할 거예요.

examples.ko: 오늘은 비가 와서 빨래 안 해요.

I practiced until late last night.
I will practice harder tomorrow.

examples.ko: 연습 안 하면 실력이 안 늘어요.
examples.en: Your skills won't improve if you don't practice.

examples.ko: 연습을 하면 누구나 잘할 수 있어요.
examples.en: Anyone can do well if they practice.
Practice and then try recording.
Practice is the way to survive (succeed).
Let's practice together.
I buy apples. And I also buy milk.
Did you do your homework? And did you study too?
Drink tea. And take some rest.
I watched a movie. And then I ate.

examples.ko: 청소를 할 거예요. 그리고 빨래도 할 거예요.
examples.en: I will clean. And I will also do laundry.

examples.ko: 비가 와요. 그리고 바람은 안 불어요.
examples.en: It's raining. And the wind is not blowing.

examples.ko: 약을 드세요. 그리고 쉬면 나을 거예요.
examples.en: Take medicine. And if you rest, you'll get better.
I exercise and then I take a shower.
And then, there was no word (silence).
Eat this. And eat that too.
I'm hungry. So I'm eating.
Is it raining? So are you taking an umbrella?
You're tired, right? So get some sleep.
There was a lot of work. So I slept late.

examples.ko: 길이 막힐 거예요. 그래서 지하철을 탈 거예요.
examples.en: The roads will be blocked. So I will take the subway.
I have no money. So I didn't buy it.

examples.ko: 아프면 어떡해? 그래서 내가 걱정하는 거야.
examples.en: What if you're sick? That's why (so) I'm worried.
It was cold, so I put on a coat and went out.
So what do you want me to do?
I'm busy. So I can't go.
Is it raining? Then stay at home.
Is it hard? Then shall I help you?
Study. Then you will pass.

examples.ko: 그가 왔어요? 그러면 왜 말 안 했어요?
examples.en: Did he come? Then why didn't you tell me?
Let's meet tomorrow. Then I'll give it to you then.
Do you hate it? Then don't do it.
If so, that would be really great.
Make a promise, then I'll believe you.
I thought so (negative/sarcastic).
Hungry? Then eat this.

usage_note: Emphasizing the reason. [Collo: 그러니까 내 말은]

examples.en: It's late. Therefore, go quickly.
Is it expensive? Is that why you won't buy it?
Since you're tired, rest here.
I was sick. That's why I went to the hospital.
Tomorrow is a holiday. That's why I'll rest.
I'm asking because I don't know, isn't it?
That's why you should have prepared in advance.
It's cold and all, so please close the door.
Exactly. (I agree with you).
That's why you should listen to me.
Korean is difficult. But it's interesting.
Are you sleepy? But you have to study, right?
It's hard. But please do a little more.
It rained. But it wasn't hot.

examples.ko: 돈이 없을 거예요. 하지만 살 거예요.
examples.en: I won't have money. But I will buy it.
I'm busy. But I'm not tired.
But I won't buy it if it's expensive.
It's small but (however) sturdy.
No "buts"!

examples.ko: 미안해. 하지만 나도 어쩔 수 없어.
examples.en: Sorry. But I can't help it either.
I went to the department store. But it was closed.
By the way, why didn't you call?
Anyway, please stop now.
I watched a movie. But it wasn't fun.

examples.ko: 내일 갈 거예요. 그런데 비가 오면 어떡하죠?
examples.en: I'll go tomorrow. But what if it rains?
Kind, but not particularly popular.
But don't buy it if it's expensive.
Tall, but (yet) wearing high heels.
However... (TV mystery show vibe).
I'm hungry. But I have no money.
It's spicy. But it's delicious.
Is it expensive? But do you still want to buy it?
You want to give up, right? But cheer up.
I was tired. However, I exercised.
It will be hard. But I will make it happen.

examples.ko: 잘 못해요. 그렇지만 안 하지는 않아요.
examples.en: Not good at it, but I don't "not do" it.
However, if you come, I'll be glad.
I'm sad, but (however) I must smile.
But what can you do.
I hate it. But I'll go.

usage_note: Refers to a continuing state. [Collo: 그래도 좋아]

examples.en: It's raining. Still, I will go.
Is it hard? Still, you can do it, right?
It's late. Even so, please say goodbye before leaving.
I was tired. Still, I finished all my homework.
It will fail. Still, I will challenge it.
It's not tasty. Still, I won't leave any.
If it's still good, do it.
It's far, but still, I want to go.
Even so, the world is worth living in.
Still, I like you.

examples.ko: 만약 비가 오면 안 갈 거예요.
examples.en: If (in case) it rains, I won't go.
What will you do if I'm not here?
(Use with ~(으)면).
If only I had known yesterday.
Even if I fail, I'll do it again.
If it doesn't work out, please tell me.
If it were me, I wouldn't do that.
If you have time, let's go together.
Prepare for the worst-case scenario.
What if (you) have no money?
If (in case) he comes, let me know.
What if it's wrong?
(Used with ~(으)면).
If that had happened, it would have been a disaster.
If I'm late tomorrow, please start first.
In case they don't come, I'll just leave.
If we succeed, let's have a party.
If it's cold, turn on the heater.
Even if there's only one in a million chance...
Let's think about the "what ifs".
Do you perhaps know him?
By any chance, have you seen my wallet?
Just in case (perhaps), take an umbrella.
Did you perhaps call yesterday?
If perhaps you have time later, let's meet.
He/She might perhaps not come.
If it perhaps rains, come to my house.
If perhaps you're hungry, eat this.
Just as I thought (My "perhaps" was "as expected").
Do you by any chance have money?
He never tells a lie.
Will you absolutely not come?
Never give up.
I can never forget yesterday.
I will absolutely never do that again.
This is absolutely not my mistake.
If it's absolutely not, I'll believe you.
I came early to never be late.
It's a desperate (absolute) crisis.
I'm absolutely not doing it!

usage_note: Requires negative ending (Formal). [Collo: 결코 포기하지 마]

examples.en: I never forget that promise.
Will you never come?
Never give up.
He never told a lie.
I will never fail.
It is by no means an easy task.
Success comes if you never give up.
It's a relief that it's by no means late.
I will not just sit back and watch (Formal).
I'll never give up.
I don't know English at all.
Are you not tired at all?
Don't worry at all.
It wasn't cold at all yesterday.
I won't come at all in the future.
I don't remember at all.
I can't buy it if there's none at all.
I didn't know at all, so I couldn't answer.
It's completely different.
I'm not bored at all.
It will probably rain.
Maybe he doesn't know, right?
(Used mostly in declarative statements).
It was probably yesterday.
I'll probably be busy tomorrow.
They probably won't come.
If so, it's probably a relief.

examples.ko: 아마 늦을 것 같아서 먼저 가요.
examples.en: I think I'll probably be late, so I'm going first.
Probably so?
It probably won't work.

usage_note: Slightly stronger emphasis than 아마. [Collo: 아마도요]

examples.en: Perhaps that's the truth.
Perhaps he has arrived?
(Guessing future/state).
It was perhaps the person who called earlier.

examples.ko: 아마도 내년에는 갈 수 있을 거예요.
examples.en: Most likely, I can go next year.
Perhaps I won't go.
If it's most likely right, that's a relief.
He perhaps forgot because he was busy.
It's most likely so.
Perhaps he won't come.
I really like Korea.
Do you really trust me?
Please be really careful on your trip.
Yesterday was really fun.
I will really wake up early tomorrow.
I really don't want to eat.
Take it if you really need it.
I was really busy, so I couldn't call.
It really feels like a dream.
You're really pretty.
This movie is really fun.
Can you really go alone?
Please give me something really delicious.
I was really surprised earlier.
I will really become rich later.
Are you sure it's really not spicy?
If it's really good, recommend it to a friend.
I was really hungry, so I ate it all.
Distinguish real from fake.
Wow, I'm really excited!
Studying Korean is very interesting.
Is the situation very serious?
Please decide very carefully.
Yesterday the weather was very cold.
The result will be very good.
It's not very high (rarely used with negation).
If you are very busy, come later.
It's very sturdy, so it lasts long.
It's a very satisfying result.
This is very expensive.
I miss my mother very much.
Are you that extremely tired?
Please handle it very preciously.
The wind blew very hard yesterday.
I will be extremely busy tomorrow.
(Commonly used with positive emotions/states).
If you're very busy, I'll help you.
It's so pretty that I keep looking.
You've gone through a lot of trouble.
I'm so happy!
My name is Chul-soo Kim.
What is the meaning of your name?
Please write your name here.
I used to be called by a different name before.
It will become a famous name later.
This is not my name.
If the names are the same, it's easy to get close.
I wrote my name and signed.
Living up to one's name.
What's your name?
Write your home address here.
What is your address?
Please let me know the accurate address.
I changed my address yesterday.
I will move to a new address soon.
This is not an accurate address.
If the address is far, take a taxi.
I checked the address and sent the package.
The address (place of residence) is unclear.
Give me your home address.
My phone number is 010-1234-5678.
Can you give me your phone number?
Please save the phone number.
I changed my phone number last week.
I will let you know the phone number tomorrow.
I don't know that person's phone number.
If the phone number is wrong, I can't contact you.
I dialed the number and waited.
Look it up in the phone book (contacts).
Hey, what's your phone number?
My nationality is Korean.
What is your nationality?
Please select your nationality.
I used to have dual nationality before.

examples.ko: 나중에 다른 국적을 가질 수도 있어요.
examples.en: I might have another nationality later.
This is not my nationality.
If the nationality is different, a visa is required.
I checked the nationality and received the documents.
Regardless of nationality, we are all friends.
What's your nationality?
My hometown is Busan.
Where is your hometown?
Please tell me some news from your hometown.
I visited my hometown during last vacation.
I want to live in my hometown someday.
Seoul is not my hometown.
I feel at peace when I go to my hometown.
I left my hometown and came to Seoul.
It has become my second hometown.
I want to go to my hometown.
My hobby is watching movies.
What is your hobby?
Try having various hobbies.
Mountain climbing used to be my hobby.
I will take up cooking as a hobby later.
I don't have any special hobbies.
If the hobbies are the same, we get close quickly.
I enjoy my hobby and relieve stress.
Try starting it as a hobby.
What's your hobby?
My specialty is singing.
Do you have a specialty of your own?
Try utilizing your special talents.
Piano has been my specialty since I was young.

examples.ko: 앞으로 더 많은 특기를 만들 거예요.
examples.en: I will develop more specialties in the future.
I'm worried because I don't have a specialty I'm good at.
Having a specialty is advantageous when getting a job.
I showcased my talent and was praised.
It's not just a talent, it's your main strength.
What's your specialty?
I do a self-introduction in Korean.
Would you mind doing a self-introduction?
Please introduce yourself with confidence.
I did a self-introduction at the interview yesterday.

examples.ko: 이따가 친구들 앞에서 자기소개 할 거예요.
examples.en: I will introduce myself in front of friends later.
I haven't prepared the self-introduction yet.
If the self-introduction is short, it won't be memorable.
I introduced myself and received applause.
It's hard to write a self-introduction letter (for jobs).
You start introducing yourself first.
Greeting happily with a smile.
Did you greet the teacher?
Greet first when you see an elder.
I exchanged greetings with a friend earlier.
I will greet you again tomorrow (honorific).
I don't greet people I don't know.
You'll be loved if you greet well.
I greeted and sat down.
People (Greetings) are everything (Personnel is management).
Hey, aren't you going to say hi?
I ask the teacher a question.
May I ask one question?
Please ask questions anytime you're curious.
I received a difficult question earlier.
I will ask the question again later.
I have no questions.
If there are many questions, it takes a long time.
I ask a question and wait for the answer.
Grasp the point of the question.
I have a question.
Answering the question kindly.
Why is there no answer?
Answer what you're asked immediately.
I couldn't answer yesterday.
I will definitely answer you tomorrow.
I don't want to answer.
I'll give you a gift if the answer is correct.
I heard the answer and nodded.
You're only good at answering (yes-man).
Answer quickly!
I understand the teacher's explanation completely.
Do you understand (honorific) my words?
Try to understand the other person's heart.
I didn't understand at all earlier.
You will come to understand everything later.
I just can't understand.
Nod your head if you understand.
I feel at peace after understanding.
Interests (understanding) are tangled.
Do you understand me?
I learn Korean at the academy every day.
What studies are you learning?
Learn humbly what you don't know.
I learned cooking yesterday.
I will learn the guitar next year.

examples.ko: 저는 아직 배울 게 많아요. (I don't know yet)
examples.en: I still have a lot to learn.
Life is joyful if you learn.
Learn and then practice.
There is no end to learning.
I want to learn this.
The teacher teaches the students.
Would you mind teaching me some Korean?
Please teach me slowly.
I taught English to my friend last week.
I will teach children later.
I'm not good at teaching.
Teaching helps me study too.
I feel a sense of accomplishment after teaching.
Don't try to lecture (teach) me.
I'll let you know (teach you).
My life in Korea is really interesting.
How is life in Korea? Is it manageable?
Please enjoy your life in Korea to the fullest.
Life in Korea at first was a bit hard.
I look forward to life in Korea even more.
Life in Korea is not always easy.
Once you adapt to life in Korea, it will get comfortable.

examples.ko: 한국 생활을 하고 친구를 많이 사귀었어요.
examples.en: I've been living in Korea and made many friends.
You've become an expert (enlightened) in Korean life.
Is life in Korea okay for you?
I'm really joyful because I'm with friends.
Was your day pleasant?
Please study joyfully.
Yesterday's party was very pleasant.
There will be many joyful things tomorrow too.
It's not that joyful.
Laughter comes if you're joyful.
It's a joyful and happy memory.
Screaming with joy (pleasant scream).
I'm so joyful!
Studying is a bit hard, but it's interesting.
What part is so difficult/tiring?
Even if it's hard, endure a little more.
Yesterday was hard because there was too much work.

examples.ko: 나중에는 이 일도 안 힘들 거예요.
examples.en: Later, this work won't be hard either.
I'm not tired at all.
If it's hard, take a break before going.
Tears came because it was hard.
This is food made with great effort (hardship).
Ah, I'm tired.

meaning: To make an effort / To strive

examples.en: I make an effort every day to be good at Korean.
How much effort have you tried?
Please try making an effort until the end.
I really strove hard to succeed.
I will make even more effort in the future.
You haven't made any effort at all.
Nothing is impossible if you make an effort.
I made an effort and practiced again.
Effort never betrays.
I'm really trying hard.
I finally passed the Korean exam!
Did you hear the news of passing?
I hope everyone passes.
I received the acceptance/passing letter yesterday.
I will definitely pass the next exam too.
Unfortunately, I didn't pass this time.
If I pass, I'll throw a party.
After passing, I called my parents.
Passed by a narrow margin (chin-up).
Hey! I passed!
I'm now graduating from 900 basic words!
When do you graduate from school?
I pray you graduate safely.
I graduated from university last week.
I will graduate by next year too.
I haven't graduated yet.
What will you do after you graduate?
I graduate and prepare for a job.
You've graduated from the beginner level now.
Congrats! Graduation, finally.
